sentences.sentence: On April 24, 2019 the City of Ottawa passed a motion(http://ottwatch.ca/meetings/meeting/7553) declaring a "climate emergency" and only two councillors voted against it.

Interestingly, one of the "No" votes came from Rick Chiarelli, second cousin of Bob Chiarelli, former Ontario Minister of Energy, who during his term was such a big booster of the renewable energy supports that have caused electricity prices to more than double in the province.The City of Ottawa's subsequent response to the emergency, its plan(https://ottawa.ca/en/living-ottawa/environment/climate-change-and-energy/energy-evolution) to get to net-zero by 2050, consists of 101 pages - which isn't actually a lot when you consider it is designing the complete upheaval of how a mid-size modern city operates.
The plan says: "Financial analysis indicates that cumulative community-wide investments from 2020 to 2050 total $57.4 billion with a present value of $31.8 billion."
To put that in perspective, it is 14.5 times the City's current annual budget(https://ottawa.ca/en/city-hall/budget/2021-budget-highlights) of $3.94 billion.

As you would expect, the plan recommends complete electrification of everything and utilizing renewable energy in the form of solar and wind - though it does not mention that they have the lowest power density among all energy sources.The plan goes on to say that its model "indicates that the minimum results required to meet the 100 per cent scenario under the electricity sector are that solar photovoltaic power "reaches 1,060 MW (megawatts) by 2050 (approximately 36 square-kilometres of solar PV47 mostly on rooftops)" while "wind generation reaches 3,218 MW by 2050 (approximately 710 large-scale turbines).

"The proposal to have 1060 MW of solar panels (40 per cent of the current capacity of the entire province) and 3,218 MW of wind turbines (60 per cent of what Ontario has currently) to supply Ottawa with the power needed to achieve net-zero by 2050 is a dream - actually a nightmare - that Ontarians have already suffered through.

Residents of Ottawa should get ready for their electricity prices to more than double every 10 years.Not surprisingly, the 101-page plan says nothing about the toxic elements in those 36 square kilometres of solar panels, which will require disposal when they reach their end-of-life in 15 to 20 years and need to be removed from the hundreds of thousands of rooftops they will cover.The same concern arises in respect to those "710 large-scale turbines" whose life cycle is about the same as solar panels' and which will be 160 metres high, compared to the Peace Tower's 98 metres.

I presume local MP Catherine McKenna, who has said she wants Ottawa to be "the greenest capital ever," will welcome solar panels on her roof and one of those industrial wind turbines just down the street.In 2019, peak electricity demand(https://www.oeb.ca/oeb/_Documents/RRR/2019_Yearbook_of_Electricity_Distributors.pdf?v=20201116) for Hydro Ottawa was 1,348 MW in the summer and 1,257 MW in winter.

By 2050, if not sooner given Ottawa's rapid population and economic growth, those peaks will double or triple, which very likely will mean Ottawa residents and businesses will be faced with rolling blackouts similar to those experienced by California, Southern Australia and Texas, three regions that have opted for unreliable and intermittent wind and solar generation.If Ottawa follows through with its plans for 2050, those of us in the rest of Ontario should insist Hydro Ottawa be disconnected from the province-wide grid so only the City of Ottawa is affected by the future blackouts or brownouts its chosen policy will have rendered inevitable.
Let them spend the $57.4 billion if they want - but only with tax dollars generated by those living in Ottawa.

The rest of us can sit back and watch what eventually happens when politicians have to face up to the harm they have done to the well-meaning but now royally pissed-off people who voted for them.Parker Gallant is a retired banker.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
